_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressors, Evaporators, Condensors, Safety Showers & Auto Purgers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary outlines Fry Foods' Risk Management Plan (RMP) submission to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for our food manufacturing facility that uses anhydrous ammonia (NH?) for refrigeration purposes. The document summarizes our approach to chemical safety, the prevention of accidental releases, emergency response measures, and our commitment to maintaining a safe and compliant operation.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
At Fry Foods, safety is a top priority. Our policies, backed by senior management commitment, emphasize the implementation of rigorous safety protocols to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia and ensure a rapid, effective response in the event of an emergency. The facility follows a structured risk management process that includes regular safety audits, continuous employee training, and adherence to relevant regulations, such as the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and EPAs Risk Management Plan requirements. We are committed to creating a safe working environment through effective safety management practices, equipment maintenance, and emergency preparedness.
Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:
Fry Foods is a food manufacturing facility specializing in the production of frozen appetizers. Our facility uses anhydrous ammonia (NH?) as the primary refrigerant in our refrigeration systems, a critical component in maintaining the quality and safety of our products. The facility handles and stores approximately 27694 pounds of anhydrous ammonia divided into north and south systems. The north system contains 18,288 lbs. and the south system contains 9406 lbs. The process involves continuous monitoring and control of ammonia levels to prevent accidents and ensure safe operation at all times.
General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
Our accidental release prevention program is

designed to minimize the potential for ammonia releases and protect both our employees and the surrounding community. Fry Foods complies with federal regulations, including the EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule and the OSHA PSM Standard, which provide a framework for managing chemical hazards. We are currently implementing a combination of technological measures (automated leak detection, automated emergency ventilation and sensors around the facility) and procedural measures (regular maintenance, inspections, and safety training for employees). Additionally, our facility conducts periodic safety audits to identify and address potential risks proactively.
Five-Year Accident History:
Over the past five years, Fry Foods has maintained a strong safety record. There have been one significant accidental release of ammonia, there were no on site or off-site injuries or environmental impacts that occurred. There was a release of 274.4 lbs. of ammonia all contained inside a frozen storage freezer and the facility was evacuated while our refrigeration contractors arrived (Kemper Northwest) to resolve the leak. We continue to monitor and evaluate our processes to ensure that any potential risks are minimized, and we are dedicated to maintaining our record of safety and compliance.
Emergency Response Program:
Our emergency response program is a critical component of our safety strategy. Fry Foods coordinates with local emergency responders, including fire and police departments, to ensure a quick and coordinated response in the event of an ammonia release, Fry Foods is not a responding facility. Public notification systems are in place to inform nearby residents if an incident occurs, ensuring that the community is aware of any potential hazards.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
Fry Foods is committed to continuous improvement in safety practices. We are currently planning the installation of additional safety features, such as advanced ammonia detection systems and impr

oved backup generators in case of power failures during an ammonia leak, to further reduce the risk of an accidental release. Additionally, we will continue to provide our employees with ongoing safety training and will conduct regular safety drills to ensure preparedness. We are also evaluating new technologies to enhance our ammonia refrigeration systems, further ensuring the safe operation of our facility.
Fry Foods is dedicated to maintaining a safe facility, preventing accidental releases, and ensuring a rapid and effective response to emergencies. Through rigorous safety protocols, employee training, and continuous improvements, we are committed to protecting our employees, the community, and the environment from potential risks associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia in our refrigeration systems.
